subject: Ethics
title: Cultural Barriers to Consent
description: One-minute skill: Cultural Barriers to Consent.

hook.text: A Navajo patient refuses to hear about possible complications. In her culture, speaking of harm invites it.

buildup.text: Western informed consent assumes patients want all information. Many cultures see full disclosure differently.

discovery.text: In Japan, doctors traditionally tell the family first. In many cultures, the elder or husband decides.

twist.text: Forcing Western consent models on every patient can itself violate autonomyâ€”imposing one culture's values.

climax.text: True respect for autonomy means asking how each patient wants to receive information, not assuming one way.

punchline.text: Consent isn't one-size-fits-all. Culture shapes the conversation.

quiz.question: Why can Western informed consent models be ethically problematic across cultures?
options: Imposing one culture's consent model on all patients can itself violate autonomy
Other cultures don't value patient health
Western medicine is always culturally appropriate
